title: Scott Askham ready for UFC London and he’s bringing the ‘Askham Army’ with him
text:
Scott Askham is under pressure to win on Saturday (Picture: Getty) Scott Askham this weekend walks into UFC Fight Night 107 in London with the knowledge that only a victory will do.
Brad Pickett: The fans' fighter retires in his hometown hoping for one more punch The UFC middleweight takes on fellow Brit Bradley Scott and following losses for both men in their last fights, another defeat could well spell the end for their current run in the promotion.
With the UFC cutting a further 19 fighters on Wednesday from their roster, the heat is certainly on for both Askham and Scott to deliver on Saturday night.
Speaking exclusively to Metro.co.uk, Askham admitted he is not quite sure what to expect from Scott.
‘To be honest, I’ve not seen all that much of him, he’s not been the most active fighter,’ Askham said.
Will @scottaskham1 take the W home after the Battle of Britain at #UFCLondon ? pic.twitter.com/SYuuz1dstW 
— #UFCLondon (@UFCEurope) March 12, 2017 

‘He fought on London thirteen months ago now and he fought [Krzysztof] Jotko who like me is a southpaw.
‘It was a good fight to watch for me to get analysis from, but to be honest I’ve not seen that much on him because he’s not fought that much.
‘I don’t know whether he’s been injured, taking time off or what not, but I know I’ve been working literally non-stop making improvements.
Bradley ‘Bear’ Scott is one half of the all-English battle (Picture: Getty) ‘Ever since I lost my last fight I’ve been working and I’m determined this Saturday to get my hand raised.’
Having moved training camps since his last fight at UFC Fight Night Hamburg last September, Askham feels he’s done all he can to give him the best possible chance of winning on fight night.

With ten weeks training at American Top Team in Florida now in the bag, Askham says he now feels in the shape of his life ahead of Saturday’s clash.
‘Going to Florida, it wasn’t like the last resort, but it was something I felt I needed to get myself to the level I need to be at,’ Askham said.
‘I felt like that was where I needed to be and it was hard leaving ASW because I genuinely felt that was home and I’ll don’t want to discredit anything I ever did there.

‘This now though is a different level and I never thought I’d train abroad at somewhere like American Top Team you know.
‘Honestly, you’ve no idea how good the move was, I feel like a different fighter now and I’m ready to show everyone what I can do.’
One thing we can be assured of on Saturday night is that Askham’s fans will travel in large numbers to The O2.
Scotty Askham's Barmy Army!! #ThrowBack #UFCBerlin 
A post shared by Scott Askham (@scottaskham1) on Nov 14, 2016 at 5:17am PST 
The man from Yorkshire has a loyal band of fans that travel with him wherever he fights.
While he promised his ‘Askham Army’ would be in attendance, Askham did mention that the atmosphere might be a little bit more split given that both fighters were from the UK.
‘Of course they are going to be there, they will be a lot of them there on Saturday,’ Askham said.
‘It might be a little bit of a weird atmosphere this one with two British guys, it could be a little quiet.
‘I hope everyone gets behind us both.

‘I’ve got my close selection of fans and that, but there will probably more neutral fans than some of the other fights on the card.
‘No doubt we will put on a cracking fight—he’s never been finished, I’ve never been finished and we both love to stand and just duke it out.
‘I’m going for a finish just like I did last year—I’m going out there to throw the full toolbox at him and for his sake, I hope he’s ready for that.’
